content:
I added "rounded" to the distance to output.
This sentence is not needed: "If there are points with the same distance, always pick the one occurring first in the list.". You could add that in the provided test cases, there is always only one solution. This allow someone to use a set for the points, and not a list.
This puzzle is too complex for a clash. It would, however, excel as a candidate for a community puzzle.
Thanks for the feedback! Yes, I have thought that as well. I have changed it to a community puzzle.

Hello,

When I reviewed your puzzle, I set a timer for myself. I was not able to solve it within 15 minutes. Now I am trying to solve it again.

Does "rounded to the next integer" mean rounding up (ceil) or down (trunc)?
If the digit in the tenth's place is lower than 5 round down otherwise round up. But only for the answer, not for the preliminary distances.

I'm still not sure why I'm not getting the same results as yours. Below outlines the steps my program goes through for test case 1:

[[234, [24, 15]], [333, [12, 30]], [106, [4, 3]], [241, [13, 27]]]
[[544, [24, 15]], [657, [13, 27]], [793, [12, 30]]]
[[265, [13, 27]], [369, [12, 30]]]
[[10, [12, 30]]]
[106, 544, 265, 10]
[[10.295630140987, 23.323807579381203, 16.278820596099706, 3.1622776601683795], 4.58257569495584]
57.64311167159213

Edit: I slipped in a complex number somewhere in by accident. Fixed. Also, improved formatting and stub generator (it now reads two ints instead of string)
